DOCNAME: CASE OF MILATOVÁ AND OTHERS v. THE CZECH REPUBLIC
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed;Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient;Costs and expenses (domestic proceedings) - claim dismissed;Costs and expenses partial award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in the GPE region .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant and her husband claimed restitution of their real property – a house with land DATE under LAW , alleging that in DATE they had been forced to sell it to the ORG , represented by the former ORG ( federální ministerstvo národní obrany ) , on terms that had been imposed on them . At the date of the entry into force of LAW , the property was managed by ORG ( “ the defendant ” ) , the authority that was obliged to return the property to them , pursuant to section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW .
CARDINAL . The restitution claim was dealt with by ORG ( pozemkový úřad ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG ( středisko geodézie ) issued a survey plan in respect of the land . The plan was , however , found to be incomplete by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant 's husband died , and their CARDINAL children joined the proceedings as his legal successors . In a medical report of DATE it was stated that the premature death of the first applicant 's husband was directly linked to an illness which had started after he had been forced to leave the house and to abandon his property .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE ORG ( katastrální úřad ) issued a new comparative plan of the land . CARDINAL other documents issued on DATE , DATE and DATE were also included in the file . CARDINAL survey plans , issued at the request of the defendant and ORG , were produced on DATE and DATE respectively .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , having assessed the material in the file and having heard evidence from CARDINAL witnesses who had been involved in the negotiations for the sale of the applicants ' property , including PERSON , who was the defendant 's lawyer , declared that the applicants were the owners of a major part of the property . It found that the contract of sale had been concluded under duress on strikingly unfavourable terms , within the meaning of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG established , among other things , that , contrary to the law then in force , the first applicant and her husband had not been considered parties to administrative proceedings which had resulted in the adoption of a decision on DATE on the location of a construction
site . It also established that the purchase price had been determined by an expert , in accordance with Decree no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . On DATE the defendant , represented by PERSON , appealed against the administrative decision to ORG ( krajský soud ) , which on DATE carried out an inspection of the site .

CARDINAL . In their observations on the defendant 's appeal , the applicants challenged , inter alia , the statement by PERSON , who had legally represented the defendant in the past and was acting again as its lawyer in the restitution proceedings .
CARDINAL . On DATE a meeting took place at the site .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the decision and remitted the case to ORG for further consideration . It stated that the existence of grounds for restitution of the property under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of LAW had not been sufficiently established .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG again decided , having taken into account further documentary evidence submitted by the first applicant and having re - examined CARDINAL witnesses , that the applicants were the owners of the property . It examined in detail the circumstances of the sale of the property . It noted , inter alia , that the first applicant 's husband had headed the defendant 's personnel department and that the defendant had needed his property for the construction of a heating plant and , subsequently , a production unit . It further noted that the first applicant 's husband had not been threatened with dismissal or the loss of his job in the event of his refusal to conclude the contract of sale .

CARDINAL . Nevertheless , ORG held that the lengthy negotiations for the sale of the applicants ' property or its expropriation , which had started in DATE , had seriously interfered with the lives of the first applicant and her husband , and that the circumstances in which these negotiations had been carried out had undoubtedly affected the health and mental state of the first applicant 's husband .

CARDINAL . ORG noted lastly that , according to the record of the negotiations dated DATE , the first applicant and her husband had agreed to the sale on condition that , inter alia , they would be provided with CARDINAL - room flats with garages , and that a CARDINAL - room apartment in a day- care home would be placed at the disposal of the first applicant 's mother . However , in addition to the price to be paid for the applicants ' property – which could have been , but had not been , increased by PERCENT as allowed by Decree no . DATE the first applicant and her husband had been granted a CARDINAL - room flat in DATE . Furthermore , a CARDINAL - room apartment had been made available to their son . In addition , it was noted that the first applicant and her late husband had lived in the house for DATE and that the benefit they had derived from the adjacent land , which they had used for agricultural purposes , had considerably improved the family 's economic and social situation .
CARDINAL . On DATE the defendant appealed against that decision . On DATE and DATE respectively the applicants and their legal representative submitted their observations on the defendant 's appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bench of ORG , after holding a hearing on DATE and receiving the applicants ' further comments concerning the case on DATE , quashed the administrative decision , finding that ORG had not proved to its satisfaction that the sale had been carried out under duress . The court considered that it was not necessary to examine whether the contract of sale had been concluded on terms unfavourable to the applicants . It held that , although ORG had reached its decision on the basis of the fully established and accurate facts of the case , it did not share its legal opinion .

CARDINAL . NORP The court noted that from the witnesses ' statements and from the documentary evidence which it had supplemented by means of the report of CARDINAL DATE on the professional activities of the first applicant 's husband , the first proposal for the purchase of the applicants ' property had been made in DATE at a time when the defendant had needed part of the land for the construction of a heating plant . The court observed that on DATE the owners had provisionally agreed to the sale and had imposed certain conditions which had to be satisfied before the construction work could be started . Moreover , they had stipulated that the sale had to be completed before DATE . At that time , both the former owners were employed ; the first applicant 's husband was employed by the defendant in a senior post and was politically active . Their economic and social situation was such that it did not create a basis for a state of duress .

Moreover , the negotiations carried out with a view to concluding the contract of sale had lasted DATE as a result of the owners ' continuous disagreement as to the fulfilment of the conditions they had imposed and the purchase price , which had finally been increased by CARDINAL NORP korunas ( CZK ) ( MONEY ( ORG ) ) .

CARDINAL . The court also noted that the purchaser had proved that it had made efforts to meet the owners ' requirements when , for instance , it had urged that a telephone line be speedily installed in CARDINAL of the new flats , had paid the telephone connection fees and had assigned the flats to them even before the contract of sale had been signed . The purchaser had only come up with the suggestion of expropriating the applicants ' property after DATE of unsuccessful negotiations .

CARDINAL . Finally , the court did not find any causal link between the contract concluded in DATE and the health problems of the first applicant 's husband , which had begun in DATE ( DATE after the contract had been signed ) , and his subsequent death in DATE .

CARDINAL . The case was remitted to ORG , which issued a fresh decision on DATE . In accordance with the opinion of ORG , by which it was bound by virtue of LAW , ORG ruled that the applicants were not the owners of the property because the contract of sale had not been concluded under duress , within the meaning of section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of LAW . ORG considered that it was therefore unnecessary to examine whether the contract of sale had been concluded on strikingly unfavourable terms within the meaning of the same provision .
CARDINAL . On DATE that decision was upheld by ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants lodged a constitutional appeal ( ústavní stížnost ) against ORG judgments of DATE and DATE and ORG decision of DATE . The applicants alleged a violation of LAW ( protection of property rights ) and CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( right to judicial protection ) of GPE práv a svobod ) . They challenged the assessment of the evidence and ORG incorrect interpretation of the notion of “ duress ” . They also criticised the failure of ORG to assess properly the notion of “ strikingly unfavourable terms ” in section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) of LAW .

CARDINAL . On DATE a judge rapporteur ( soudce zpravodaj ) invited ORG and the parties joined to the proceedings – ORG , ORG and ORG ( Pozemkový fond ) DATE to submit written observations on the applicants ' constitutional appeal .
CARDINAL . NORP In letters of CARDINAL and DATE respectively , ORG and ORG waived their status as joined parties .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG submitted its written observations , expressing the view that the applicants ' constitutional appeal should be dismissed .

CARDINAL . In its written observations of DATE , ORG recapitulated the case - law to the effect that ORG was not superior to the general courts and that it was not entitled to interfere with their decisions unless and in so far as they might have infringed rights and freedoms protected by LAW . It further referred to the reasoning in its judgment of DATE , and noted that the constitutional appeal had been lodged outside the DATE time - limit in so far as it was directed against ORG judgment of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judge rapporteur asked ORG and ORG to forward their case files , which they did .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) , without holding a public hearing , declared that the constitutional appeal had been lodged outside the DATE time - limit in so far as it was directed against ORG judgment of DATE and was unsubstantiated in so far as it concerned the same court 's judgment of DATE . ORG included the written observations of the defendant and ORG on the applicants ' constitutional appeal in its summary of the facts . It stated , inter alianection that it could not examine issues falling within the jurisdiction of the ordinary courts . The court , recapitulating briefly the reasoning of the national authorities involved in the case , did not find unconstitutional ORG conclusion that the hypothesis that the applicants had been under duress during the contractual negotiations was excluded by the fact that they had imposed certain conditions on which they were willing to conclude the contract with the ORG , and that someone acting under duress would have concluded the contract on any terms .

CARDINAL . According to the Government , it appears from ORG case file that on DATE the first applicant inspected the documents included in the file and was provided with copies of the written observations submitted by ORG and ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW provides for the restitution of real property to individuals from whom it was transferred to ORG ownership DATE and DATE by means specified in section CARDINAL . Where such persons are no longer alive , their successors are entitled to restitution under the conditions specified in subsection ( CARDINAL ) of section CARDINAL .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(k ) provides for the restitution of immovable property which was transferred to the ORG or another legal person on the basis of a contract concluded under duress , on strikingly unfavourable terms .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , the parties to proceedings are the appellant and those specified by LAW Persons to whom the LAW grants the status of joined parties may waive that status . They have the same rights and duties as other parties to the proceedings .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL provides that parties and joined parties are entitled to give their views on the constitutional appeal , make submissions to ORG , examine the case file ( with the exception of voting records ) , take excerpts from and copies of it , take part in any oral hearing in the matter , put forward evidence , and be present during any taking of evidence .
CARDINAL . Under section ORG ) , if the request concerns a matter within the jurisdiction of a division , it is assigned to a judge rapporteur who is a permanent member of that division .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , the judge rapporteur must , without delay , send the constitutional appeal to the other parties and , where appropriate , to the joined parties as well , with a request to submit their written observations on the appeal within time - limits fixed by him or her , or as provided by the Act .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) provides that , without holding an oral hearing and without the parties being present , the division may dismiss the appeal if it is manifestly ill - founded .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that any means which may serve to establish the facts of the case may be used in evidence , in particular the testimony of witnesses , expert opinions , reports and statements of ORG authorities and legal persons , documents , results of inquiries and the testimony of parties .
